evidence.text: This action seeks to halt the U.S. Department of Labor’s (“DOL”) unlawful efforts to eliminate Job Corps, the nation’s largest residential career training program.

extracted.value: The action seeks to halt the U.S. Department of Labor’s unlawful efforts to eliminate Job Corps, the nation’s largest residential career training program.

evidence.text: Nevertheless, starting in mid-March 2025, DOL, at the direction of DOGE, has taken steps to eliminate Job Corps—culminating in its May 29, 2025, decision to cease operations of all contractor-based Job Corps centers.

extracted.value: Starting in mid-March 2025, DOL has taken steps to eliminate Job Corps—culminating in its May 29, 2025, decision to cease operations of all contractor-based Job Corps centers.

evidence.text: Job Corps, established by Congress in 1964, is the nation’s largest residential employment and workforce development program for youth.

extracted.value: Job Corps, established by Congress in 1964, is the nation’s largest residential employment and workforce development program for youth.

evidence.text: Job Corps currently serves approximately 25,000 students and has trained and educated over three million individuals since 1964.

extracted.value: Job Corps currently serves approximately 25,000 students and has trained and educated over three million individuals since 1964.

evidence.text: DOL halted applicant background checks, which effectively prevented new enrollment, as students must pass a background check when they are admitted.

extracted.value: DOL halted applicant background checks, which effectively prevented new enrollment.

evidence.text: On April 11, 2025, DOL discontinued dedicated student Career Transition Readiness (“CTR”) programs and student medical testing requirements.

extracted.value: On April 11, 2025, DOL discontinued dedicated student Career Transition Readiness (“CTR”) programs and student medical testing requirements.

evidence.text: On April 23, 2025, all pending or outstanding Job Corps procurements except for three were abruptly canceled.

extracted.value: On April 23, 2025, all pending or outstanding Job Corps procurements except for three were abruptly canceled.

evidence.text: On April 25, 2025, DOL released a “Job Corps Transparency Report,” which applies a flawed methodology and reflects selective and inaccurate performance measures, costs, and statistics.

extracted.value: On April 25, 2025, DOL released a “Job Corps Transparency Report,” which applies a flawed methodology.

evidence.text: On April 30, 2025, DOL effectively terminated its provision of internet service to Job Corps campuses.

extracted.value: On April 30, 2025, DOL effectively terminated its provision of internet service to Job Corps campuses.

evidence.text: On May 29, 2025, DOL had a call with all Job Corps operators to announce its plan to implement stop work orders on all Job Corps contracts nationwide.

extracted.value: On May 29, 2025, DOL had a call with all Job Corps operators to announce its plan to implement stop work orders on all Job Corps contracts nationwide.

evidence.text: The notices state: “You shall begin immediately all work necessary to provide a safe, orderly, and prompt shutdown of center operations.”

extracted.value: The notice states: “You shall begin immediately all work necessary to provide a safe, orderly, and prompt shutdown of center operations.”

evidence.text: Plaintiff National Job Corps Association (“NJCA”) is a 501(c)(6) national member trade organization, founded in 1998.

extracted.value: Plaintiff National Job Corps Association (“NJCA”) is a 501(c)(6) national member trade organization, founded in 1998.

evidence.text: Plaintiff Adams and Associates, Inc. (“Adams”), is a 100% employee‑owned company founded in 1990, with more than 1,900 employee shareholders across the country.

extracted.value: Plaintiff Adams and Associates, Inc. (“Adams”) is a 100% employee‑owned company founded in 1990, with more than 1,900 employee shareholders across the country.

evidence.text: Plaintiff Education & Training Resources, LLC (“ETR”) was founded in 1991, and has been serving as a Job Corps operator since 1997.

extracted.value: Plaintiff Education & Training Resources, LLC (“ETR”) was founded in 1991, and has been serving as a Job Corps operator since 1997.

evidence.text: Plaintiff Alternate Perspectives, Inc. (“API”) was founded in 2004. Job Corps makes up over 98% of API’s business.

extracted.value: Plaintiff Alternate Perspectives, Inc. (“API”) was founded in 2004; Job Corps makes up over 98% of API’s business.

evidence.text: Plaintiff Strategix Management LLC (“Strategix Management”) was founded in 2016, serves 1,348 students across four Job Corps Center campuses.

extracted.value: Plaintiff Strategix Management LLC (“Strategix Management”) was founded in 2016, serves 1,348 students across four Job Corps Center campuses.

evidence.text: Plaintiff Transportation Communications Union / IAM (“TCU”) is a federal labor union representing approximately 35,000 members.

extracted.value: Plaintiff Transportation Communications Union / IAM (“TCU”) is a federal labor union representing approximately 35,000 members.

evidence.text: Plaintiff Jocelyn (“Kota”) Rivera is an eighteen‑year‑old student at Glenmont Job Corps Center in Callicoon, New York.

extracted.value: Plaintiff Jocelyn (“Kota”) Rivera is an eighteen‑year‑old student at Glenmont Job Corps Center in Callicoon, New York.

evidence.text: Defendant U.S. Department of Labor (“DOL”) is a federal agency.

extracted.value: Defendant U.S. Department of Labor (“DOL”) is a federal agency.

evidence.text: Job Corps participants include homeless, foster care, and other disadvantaged youth.

extracted.value: Job Corps participants include homeless, foster care, and other disadvantaged youth.
